Question: What is the purpose of TheHive, an open source Security Incident Response Platform (SIRP)? https://flare.io/learn/resources/blog/open-source-threat-intelligence/
Ground Truth: TheHive facilitates collaboration and information sharing among security teams by integrating with numerous threat intelligence feeds. It allows organizations to effectively manage incidents and analyze threat data.

Question: Which open source threat intelligence feeds seamlessly integrate with the Smart SOAR platform? https://d3security.com/blog/10-of-the-best-open-source-threat-intelligence-feeds/
Ground Truth: The feeds listed here integrate seamlessly with the Smart SOAR platform.

Question: What types of websites are frequently targeted by attackers? https://www.fortinet.com/resources/cyberglossary/web-security-threats
Ground Truth: Attackers frequently target popular websites that rely on open-source content management systems (CMS), such as Joomla, Magento, and WordPress. For example, in June 2020, a cyberattack targeted 1.3 million WordPress sites in an attempt to download configuration files and database credentials.

Question: How can organizations find out if their data has been exposed on the deep web? https://flare.io/learn/resources/blog/threat-intelligence-sources/
Ground Truth: SocRadar provides a free Deep Web Report for organizations to check if their data has been exposed.

Question: What is ZAP, and how does it help scan web applications for vulnerabilities? https://www.stationx.net/open-source-cyber-security-tools/
Ground Truth: ZAP is an all-in-one web-app scanner tool that scans web apps for vulnerabilities and can also alter HTTPS requests. It’s a free, open source alternative to Burp Suite.

Question: Why is Metasploit popular among penetration testers, and what features does it offer? https://www.stationx.net/open-source-cyber-security-tools/
Ground Truth: Metasploit is widely used for testing and developing exploits against target machines. It automates vulnerability scanning and allows easy deployment of payloads.

Question: How does ONYPHE aggregate threat intelligence data, and what sources does it use? https://cybersecuritynews.com/cyber-security-search-engines/
Ground Truth: ONYPHE is a cybersecurity data search engine that aggregates various sources for threat intelligence and monitoring.

Question: What is Grep App, and how does it help discover security vulnerabilities in open-source repositories? https://cybersecuritynews.com/cyber-security-search-engines/
Ground Truth: Grep App is a code search engine specifically designed for finding security patterns and vulnerabilities in open-source code.

Question: What are some free tools from GitHub or GitLab that can benefit sysadmins, threat intel analysts, and software developers? https://www.csoonline.com/article/555805/19-open-source-github-projects-for-security-pros.html
Ground Truth: GitHub hosts various open source projects for security professionals, including tools for forensics, malware analysis, and secure software development.

Question: What is the purpose of the Content-Security-Policy (CSP) security header? https://infosec.mozilla.org/guidelines/web_security
Ground Truth: A CSP header restricts the sources from which a web page can load scripts, styles, and other resources, mitigating cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

Question: What is the goal of a security.txt file on a website? https://securitytxt.org/
Ground Truth: A security.txt file provides a central location for website owners to disclose their vulnerability reporting policies and contact information for security researchers.

Question: What is a common use case for the OpenSSL library? https://www.openssl.org/
Ground Truth: OpenSSL is a widely used open-source library that provides secure communication protocols like HTTPS and encryption algorithms.

Question: How can threat intelligence platforms like Maltego be used in cybersecurity? https://www.maltego.com/solutions/cyber-threat-intelligence/
Ground Truth: Maltego is a link analysis tool that helps security professionals visualize relationships between malicious actors, domains, and infrastructure.

Question: What information might a security researcher find in a security.txt file? https://securitytxt.org/
Ground Truth: Security researchers can find contact details for reporting vulnerabilities and responsible disclosure policies in a security.txt file.

Question: What types of feeds does Spamhaus offer? https://www.securityzones.net/spamhaus/advanced-threat-feeds/#:~:text=Advanced%20Threat%20Feeds%20From%20Spamhaus,infected%20hosts%2C%20and%20related%20metadata.
Ground Truth: Botcc, eXBL, eDBL, eCSS and Passive DNS — provide the most current, detailed, and actionable intelligence on botnets, infected hosts, and related metadata.

Question: What is the role of OSINT in cybersecurity? https://www.imperva.com/learn/application-security/open-source-intelligence-osint/#:~:text=Open%20Source%20Intelligence%20(OSINT)%20is,national%20intelligence%20agencies%2C%20or%20cybercriminals.
Ground Truth: Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) is a method of gathering information from public or other open sources, which can be used by security experts, national intelligence agencies, or cybercriminals.

Question: What is a "pass-the-hash" attack? https://www.crowdstrike.com/cybersecurity-101/pass-the-hash/
Ground Truth: Pass the hash (PtH) is a type of cybersecurity attack in which an adversary steals a “hashed” user credential and uses it to create a new user session on the same network

Question: Why is CVE-2017-11882 frequently exploited? https://medium.com/@asmcybersecurity/cve-2017-11882-is-a-distinct-common-vulnerabilities-and-exposures-cve-entry-denoting-a-security-e44f886f3ca1
Ground Truth: It can be exploited via the mere act of opening a document or email.

Question: How many phases are there in the Cyber Kill Chain model? https://www.lockheedmartin.com/en-us/capabilities/cyber/cyber-kill-chain.html#:~:text=The%20model%20identifies%20what%20the,adversary's%20tactics%2C%20techniques%20and%20procedures.
Ground Truth: Seven steps.

Question: What type of information is available in the Exploit-Kit Galaxy? https://misp-galaxy.org/exploit-kit/
Ground Truth: It includes document, browser and router exploit kits

Question: What is the PyMISP library used for? https://www.circl.lu/doc/misp/pymisp/
Ground Truth: to access MISP platforms via their REST API.

Question: What is the role of CISA's Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog? https://www.armosec.io/glossary/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog-kev/#:~:text=The%20purpose%20of%20KEV%20is,%2C%20media%2C%20and%20government%20agencies.
Ground Truth: The purpose of KEV is to provide a timely and authoritative source of information on CVEs that have been verified to be exploited by malicious actors based on open-source reporting and analysis from various sources, such as security vendors, researchers, media, and government agencies.

Question: What is the purpose of the Cyber Kill Chain model? https://darktrace.com/cyber-ai-glossary/cyber-kill-chain#:~:text=The%20Cyber%20Kill%20Chain%20is,to%20achieving%20the%20attacker's%20objective.
Ground Truth: It serves as a framework for understanding and analyzing the different phases of an attack, from the initial reconnaissance to achieving the attacker's objective.

Question: What vulnerability was exploited in the Heartbleed attack? https://nordvpn.com/blog/what-is-heartbleed-bug/#:~:text=It%20allows%20the%20exploitation%20of,into%20giving%20away%20sensitive%20information%2C
Ground Truth: Hackers use Heartbleed to trick a vulnerable SSL/TLS server into giving away sensitive information, including usernames and passwords.

Question: How many weaponized vulnerabilities were found in Apache HTTP Server between 2017 and 2021? https://www.trendmicro.com/en_gb/research/22/b/recent-cyberattacks-open-source-web-servers.html
Ground Truth: 31 vulnerabilites

Question: What attack method was used in the 2012 Shamoon attack on Saudi Aramco? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shamoon#:~:text=It%20was%20initiated%20by%20a,company's%20network%20around%20mid%2D2012.
Ground Truth: phishing email attack

Question: What is COSMICENERGY? https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/cosmicenergy-ot-malware-russian-response
Ground Truth: COSMICENERGY is a novel OT/ICS-oriented malware identified by Mandiant, designed to cause electric power disruption by interacting with IEC-104 devices.

Question: What are the two main components of COSMICENERGY?  https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/cosmicenergy-ot-malware-russian-response
Ground Truth: The two main components of COSMICENERGY are PIEHOP and LIGHTWORK.

Question: What year was the ICS-focused malware IRONGATE identified by the FLARE team? https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/irongate-ics-malware
Ground Truth: The FLARE team identified IRONGATE in the latter half of 2015.

Question: What utility does IRONGATE use, and how is it executed by the dropper? https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/irongate-ics-malware
Ground Truth: IRONGATE uses the NirSoft NetResView utility, which is executed by the dropper using the command audiodg.exe /scomma scxrt2.ini.
